comments.commentBody:
One of the worst aspects is how time consuming it is for the me to dispute Doctor bills after each visit because my $ 1700 per month insurance refuses to pay because the doctor billed something wrong or some part of it is not covered.
I think that is a money saving strategy for insurances, because it makes you want to avoid doctor visits.
Can't blame them alone. The health care system seems like a self serve ice cream shop for providers. The prices for healthcare services are insane.

Speak for yourself, tens of millions of us Americans dont identify with your racially and religiously based ideology and identity and would vigorously and proudly defeat it at home even before it got a chance to be defeated abroad.

Richard, you are being too clever by half.  I don't think that "tumor" is the most apt metaphor for the alt-right.  Perhaps trump and people like Bannon who work for him really don’t totally identify with what you call "a small group of hyper-racist Americans".  But their relationship is mutually beneficial, sort of like a relationship found in nature between a parasite and its host.  Maybe that’s The Art of the Deal in action, but it’s a Faustian deal that should not belong in the White House.

You should study history more diligently. The Russian Empire ruthlessly conquered and oppressed tens of millions of Non-Orthodox Slavs in Eastern Europe, the Ottoman Balkans, Crimea, and the Caucasus as well as Siberia and Central Asia.
Wrong, this has always been bitterly contested in Russia itself by the Pan-Slavists and Orthodox nationalists.

"Extremists Turn to Putin to Protect Western Values"?

Since when have extremist, right-wing views and crypto-despotism had ANYTHING to do with "Western values"?

It means, of course, traditional Western values, those that progressives reject as obsolete and label “far right.” Putin often, apparently sincerely, champions Christianity. Progressives’ inability to see that this position is not “extreme” made them totally unprepared for the result of the U.S. election.
A good number of the Founders thought that "championing Christianity" was extreme.  Groups like TWP or people like Jerry Falwell Jr. aren't so much Christians as they are Christianists.

So right Jade.

As to your $32,000/yr income, it would only fill the 20,100 gal fuel tank to a 1/3 on the Déjà Vu yacht - let alone tip the crew of 11, feed them, docking charges, maintenance, insurance, permits, taxes - um, never mind the taxes - and many other expenses.

The 1% also represent the worst carbon emitters in history and contaminate our planet exponentially above the rest of us with their frivolous waste.

As stateless people - who take from nations while avoiding paying their fair dues/taxes to these nations like the rest of us - they should remain completely stateless and not derive wealth or income and benefit or protections from any state. See how well they "profit" from that.

"deep Hayekian insights"! Ross Douthat can be more Catholic than the Pope, whose tolerance for the human condition seems to bother him more than the risks facing our planet.

https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/nov/14/neoliberalsim-dona...

"[Hayek] rejects such notions as political freedom, universal rights, human equality ... all of which, by restricting the behaviour of the wealthy and powerful, intrude on the absolute freedom from coercion he demands.

"Democracy, by contrast, “is not an ultimate or absolute value”. In fact, liberty depends on preventing the majority from exercising choice over the direction that politics and society might take.

"a heroic narrative of extreme wealth .... the very rich should be free ... without constraint by public interest or public opinion."

"The progress of society depends on the liberty ... to gain as much money as they want and spend it how they wish. All that is good and useful, therefore, arises from inequality. There should be no connection between merit and reward, no distinction made between earned and unearned income, and no limit to the rents they can charge.

"Hayek softened his opposition to monopolies and hardened his opposition to trade unions. He lambasted progressive taxation and attempts by the state to raise the general welfare of citizens. He insisted that there is “an overwhelming case against a free health service for all” and dismissed the conservation of natural resources."

Your observation on Mr. Douthat being more Catholic than a Jesuit. That seems to be an affliction that is often suffered by converts to a religion other than the one they grew up in. Add to that a natural bent toward conservatism and... you get Ross Douthat.

It's really sad he doesn't get the point of the Pope's teachings when so many non-Catholics do.

"I have always said that I am in favor of a minimum income for every person in the country."
Hayek on Hayek: An Autobiographical Dialogue by F. A. Hayek, edited by Stephen Kresge and Leif Wenar (Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1994)

In August, 1969, President Richard Nixon proposed the replacement of AFDC with a program that would benefit “the working poor, as well as the nonworking; to families with dependent children headed by a father, as well as those headed by a mother.”
“What I am proposing is that the Federal Government build a foundation under the income of every American family with dependent children that cannot care for itself — and wherever in America that family may live.” Richard Nixon, 1969
Hayek moved from the United States to Germany in his later years to enjoy the social safety net for which he qualified.

Don't forget not paying his fair share of taxes--in effect requiring taxpayers to carry his freight; $1B in just one year. Who knows what the rest of the unpaid taxes amount to? And he still hasn't disclosed his IRS returns.
Or you could play several other varieties.  Like flag football, or skeleton practices.  People love football and are not giving it up easily.
You decide your major not the coaches.
Proper tackling is not designed to injure, but many don't learn this but rather hitting.
It is?  In no other sport is team work as important, nor is strategy either.
If Selig and Steinbrenner (evil tweedle-dip and tweedle dumb) go into the Hall of Fame as Pete Rose waits outside the Hall will be rendered a sham and a shame.
Neither of these men deserves a place in any hall of fame, unless one is constructed to honor contributions to untrammeled greed.

Horrific to think that Marvin Miller, who as head of the MLB players association negotiated fair employment rules for players would still not be voted into the hall and a convicted felon, who was permanently banned from baseball in 1990 (later reinstated) George Steinbrenner has a chance to get in to the HOF.

Selig and Steinbrenner in the Baseball Hall of Fame? Pleeaaze!

Selig had NO real accomplishments in baseball and presided over the Billionaire Boys Club of owners running totally amok and trashing what was left of baseball as Head Owner. And he was part of the owners' coup d'etat, deposing the last non-toady commissioner and then claiming "I'm not really the Commissioner of Baseball" before Congress! I don't think so...

And as for Steinbrenner, it's hard to know where to start... Banned from baseball (for paying a known gambler to dig up dirt on HIS OWN star player, Dave Winfield!)... A felon, who pleaded guilty to making illegal contributions to Nixon's re-election campaign, and obstruction of justice, and was banned from baseball for two years... Perhaps if the Hall has a "Men of Infamy and Disgrace" wing?

And as for Steinbrenner as a "loyal friend,” why not ask Dave Winfield, or Reggie Jackson, who are in the Hall, about Steinbrenner's "loyalty" and "friendship"?

Photo

Hillary was going to do that, but you appear not to have wanted to know. From the New Yorker summary (middle paragraph 2 below):

"a series of thoughtful and energetic proposals that present precisely the kind of remedies that could improve the lives of many working-class and poor Americans of all races. She would simplify the tax code for small businesses and streamline their licensing requirements. ....

"Clinton’s tax plans are also designed to promote broader-based affluence. She would increase the tax rate on short-term capital gains for high earners, with lower rates for longer-term holdings; close the “carried-interest” tax loophole that favors hedge-fund managers; and levy fees on banks with high debt levels. She would impose a four-per-cent surcharge on incomes above five million dollars a year, and adopt a minimum thirty-per-cent tax rate on incomes above a million dollars a year. She supports an “exit tax” and other fiscal adjustments that would discourage so-called corporate inversion—the offshoring of companies to tax havens like Ireland. And she proposes tax incentives for investing in towns that have faced significant losses in manufacturing jobs. To address the compounding effects of trade and technology on displaced workers, she would promote training, and include a tax credit for businesses that take on apprentices. She would allocate $275 billion over five years to infrastructure improvement, focussing on transit and water systems ..."
When you believe in fairy tales, anything is possible.

The point (and irony) is that the world of high level college athletics involves complete disregard of the professed values in the "fairy tales", including in religious affiliated schools. In truth, consistent religious beliefs have often been very beneficial to society.
What a mess.
comments.userLocation: Lewis Family Farm, Essex, N. Y.

comments.commentBody: Interestingly, Evangelicals went 81% for Trump and 16% for Clinton:  the religious demographic/designation that gave Trump the highest percentage. I wonder if they even try to call themselves "values voters" anymore, and if they do, what "values" are they looking for in a candidate?
Rest assured Trump will be making them squirm through his actions, past present and future. He can't help himself.

So disgusting that they hide behind the mantle of forgiveness when they have such callous disregard for the safety of their students. This man is a monster who oversaw the systematic coverup of horrible crimes. He should be in jail.
Indeed, the real religion taught at Liberty U. is Dominionism, not Christianity.

There are probably no universities that have not, at one time or another, defended their jocks, most often football players, against charges of sexual abuse against women. They have attacked and expelled the victims of sexual assault to protect their sports teams. However, most universities do not invoke God in their rules of behavior. Both Baylor and Liberty have honor code based on their interpretation of the bible, just as BYU attacks the victims of rape as having violated the honor code. It is fair to attack religious based university as being especially hypocritical. The other universities are bad actors but they don't pretend to invoke God's laws.

Tribe (and football) first, decency and morality - wherever.

Jesus wept.
